However, such uncomfortable or even harsh treatment did not lead to resistance due to the influence of Confucianism. On the one hand, citizens thought confrontation was rude and not harmonious. On the other hand, they viewed the uncomfortable interactions in a more "positive energy" way; they considered that the harsh treatment was the superordinates' natural reaction when working extremely hard. With such recognition, Chinese people chose to cooperate with the contact tracing checkers. Another type was to include marginalized people. Citizens understood that the infrastructure excluded people who did not have or did not know how to use smartphones. Digital infrastructures built on smartphone apps have been long criticized due to the exclusion of people who were not tech-savvy [82]. Most of the people are seniors, whose children are otherwise good at using advanced technologies like smart devices. Out of benevolence or propriety, participants did the work of helping marginalized people, who were usually their parents, use digital contact tracing. The work also accelerated the expansion of the infrastructure, getting more citizens included in the network.

In addition to raising awareness and motivating work, Chinese culture also had an important role of stigmatization that prevents people from resisting the adoption. When most people had adopted the infrastructure, it created social pressure, especially in a collectivist society, on people who had not adopted it. In our study, we observed the anxiety created by the social pressure among citizens who did not use the contact tracing apps. We also saw people gave up resisting the infrastructure due to the fear of being stigmatized [100]. Collectivism and Confucianism granted social meanings to the infrastructure, and the strong influence of culture behind the infrastructure caused power asymmetry, which finally prevented resistance and contributed to adoption.

As a summary, culture played an important role in the adoption of digital contact tracing infrastructure in China, including raising infrastructure awareness, motivating infrastructuring work, and preventing resistance. Such insights could help future studies better understand large-scale infrastructure implementation in collectivism or Confucianism contexts.

div.head: LIMITATIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: This study might have some limitations due to the sampling method. Our data was collected from 26 Chinese residents. The recruitment process was not random: the authors recruited participants from their social network and by recommendation from the participants. The non-random sampling process might influence the generalizability of the results our For example, most of our participants have a high education background, so people with lower education levels might be underrepresented in our project. That said, this study yields insightful findings on Chinese culture's influence on residents' interactions with infrastructure in crises, laying a solid ground for future research.

In terms of future work, we propose several directions. 1) Future studies can delve into residents' more specific culturally-induced interactions within a human infrastructure. For example, our work revealed that stigmatization, one type of social pressure, contributed to Chinese citizens' adoption of digital contact tracing, contradicting a recent research that reported stigmatization in Japan would prevent residents from doing so [35]. The contradiction could be partially explained by the specific context where stigmatization took place. For instance, compared to Japan, the outbreak in China was somehow more effectively controlled because of a series of compulsory regulations, and the possibility of infection was low. Therefore, participants of our study only had concerns of stigmatization due to not being cooperative to the government but did not have the concerns of stigmatization due to being infected by the virus. That said, future research can be done to deeply investigate such contradiction in terms of contextualized stigmatization. 2) Researchers can investigate digital contact tracing oriented human infrastructure in China from a long term perspective. Semaan [76] has pointed out that, during crisis, people modify their social lives through ICTs and therefore create new forms of social arrangements (i.e. new human infrastructure). While in our study we have noticed that participants did use digital contact tracing to shape their social lives, we did not observed new social relationships. One possible explanation is that our interview took place a few months after the implementation of the technology; it was too short for citizens to create a new form of social relationships. Therefore, long-term studies can be conducted in the future to explore the potential new social arrangements among Chinese citizens.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: In the study, we are interested in how Chinese citizens adopted digital contact tracing in the COVID-19 pandemic. We take a qualitative approach to address the question. We interview 26 participants and use thematic analysis to interpret their experiences. Our findings show that in the pandemic, digital contact tracing becomes an infrastructure where citizens have to rely on. It influences participants' lives at multiple levels. Chinese citizens, who are driven by collectivism and Confucianism, form a human infrastructure to support the digital contact tracing infrastructure. Our paper points out a new direction of human infrastructure studies that considers culture as a focal point.

figure.figDesc: Figure 3: Residents scanning QR Code at checkpoints (left [6]) and showing Health Code to checkers (right [16])

Critiquing the Local Implementation of Digital Contact Tracing. According to our participants, similar regulations, including requiring people to install, use, and present digital contact tracing, are deployed in many local organizations, like apartment, universities, factories, companies, and so on. Participants recalled their experiences with the organizations and evaluated the local implementation of digital contact tracing. Over half of them (16 out of 26) were not satisfied with the local management. P8 told us her story after she came back from Hubei, the province where the epicenter of the outbreak, Wuhan City, belongs to:

row.cell: Before I came back to my apartment, I had been to
Hubei Province. After I was back, the pandemic broke
out, and the local authorities were looking for people
who had been to Hubei. So I reported my travel history
to my apartment management. But after I reported,
I constantly got phone calls asking me questions. The
managers came to my house and let me take tests and fill
in forms. It...made you feel stressed, and it was like you
were very special. Then they would categorize you as
people who have been to Wuhan, recorded your identity
and travel information, and they even publicized the
information right at the entrance of the building! It is
not acceptable to me. That's why I am concerned about
the Health Code. What if the information is disclosed?
What if people know someone comes from Wuhan and
then they discriminate against this person? [P8]

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: We thank our interviewees for their valuable experiences with contact tracing apps. We also thank the CHI reviewers for their constructive comments. Lastly, we thank Dr Yubo Kou and Dr Xinning Gui for their insightful instructions.
